But some sports doctors say the information can help identify disorders that put athletes at greater risk for injury.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: A photo shows students in Lviv celebrating Adolf Hitler’s birthday.
Justification: An image of Russians forming the number 55 to celebrate the anniversary of Yuri Gagarin rocketing into space has been mischaracterized to wrongly claim that it shows Ukrainian students celebrating Hitler’s birthday.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Will Smith slapped Chris Rock “to take attention away from Ukraine.”
Justification: There’s no evidence to support the unfounded claim that Will Smith slapping Chris Rock at the Academy Awards was staged to take attention away from Ukraine.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Says Tucker Carlson said, “What if these bodies of tortured, dead civilians were staged? What if they’re fake? What if the Ukrainian military killed them & then blamed Russia? I’m not saying any of this is true, I’m just asking the questions. Why can’t we ask these questions?”
Justification: Some people have interpreted a tweet about Tucker Carlson and Ukraine to mean that he suggested the country staged dead bodies. But he didn’t say that.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Video shows the final moments aboard China Eastern Airlines flight 5735 before it crashed.
Justification: The footage does not doesn’t show any real plane crash. The clip is a flight simulation video of an Ethiopian plane crash that occurred in Kenya in 2019.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: "Books banned in Texas include 1984, Maus, and The Handmaid's Tale, but not Mein Kampf."
Justification: A popular tweet claimed "1984" by George Orwell, "Maus" by Art Spiegelman, "The Handmaid's Tale" by Margaret Atwood, and Hitler's manifesto "Mein Kampf" are banned in Texas. The tweet doesn't specify whether it is referring to public or school libraries, though the latter has seen a wave of book challenges. The tweet also doesn't specify whether it pertains to a specific school district or Texas Rep. Krause's letter to superintendents in October 2021 requesting nearly 850 titles be catalogued and investigated in school libraries. Rep. Krause's list does not mention these titles except for "The Handmaid's Tale: Graphic Novel" by Margaret Atwood and Renee Nault. There is no state ban of these titles and no districts that PolitiFact Texas knows of that banned these titles, after conferring with librarian organizations.
Sources: " The Handmaid's Tale: Full Book Summary
Phone interview with Robert G. "Rob" Weiner

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “We haven’t seen a single American megachurch offer anything to help Ukrainians.”
Justification: Multiple megachurches around the United States have been raising funds to help Ukrainians during Russia’s invasion.
Sources: The United Methodist Committee on Relief

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Says Bob Saget died from the COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: Bob Saget was found dead on Jan. 9 and the cause and manner of his death have not yet been released, but claims that he died as a result of receiving a COVID-19 vaccine booster a month earlier are being made without evidence.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “With the money Elon Musk spent to buy Twitter shares, he could have given every American family $100,000 and still had enough left over to cancel all student debt.”
Justification: The Twitter post was a joke and did not seriously argue that Elon Musk should have used the money he spent on buying Twitter shares to give every American family $100,000. Even if it was serious, the math is wrong. $3 billion divided by 122 million households would be $24.59 for each family with nothing leftover to cancel student debt. Americans owe an estimated $1.74 trillion in student loans.
Sources: Archive of Hunter Walk’s Twitter post
Archive of Hunter Walk’s Twitter reply

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: "GOP Sen. Marsha Blackburn has proposed that birth control should only be legal for MARRIED couples.”
Justification: A 1965 Supreme Court ruling (Griswold v. Connecticut) overturned a state ban on contraception, citing a right to marital privacy. Sen. Marsha Blackburn, R-Tenn., criticized the decision as "constitutionally unsound," though she did not explain how. Blackburn did not propose limiting contraceptive use to married couples, nor did she otherwise make any proposals about birth control.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: The mass shooting in Buffalo, New York was a “false flag event.”
Justification: There is overwhelming evidence, including witness testimony, news reports and government investigations, that prove that the mass shooting at a grocery store in Buffalo, New York, happened. Conspiracy theories that label real crises as fake far outnumber actual false flag events.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: A video shows that “OnlyFans has guys on campus encouraging your daughters to do porn for ‘financial freedom.’”
Justification: OnlyFans is an internet subscription platform popular for hosting adult content. A viral tweet shared a video from Instagram and claimed that it showed "OnlyFans has guys on campus encouraging your daughters to do porn for ‘financial freedom.’" The original video appeared to be created as a joke, based on the caption and comments on Instagram and other platforms. The man seen in the video, a social media influencer, is not employed by or affiliated with OnlyFans, the company confirmed. A spokesperson for Florida International University, where the original Instagram video was filmed, said the man was quickly asked to leave the campus.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “The Russian army captured the U.S Major General Roger L. Cloutier Jr. … in the besieged Ukrainian Azov camp in Mariupol.”
Justification: Lt. Gen. Roger L. Cloutier Jr., commander of NATO’s Allied Land Command, has not been captured by Russian forces in Mariupol, the Allied Land Command confirmed. Cloutier posted photos from a recent event in Turkey to his LinkedIn profile, where he disputed the internet rumors alleging that he had been captured.
Sources: NATO Allied Land Command on Facebook
NATO Allied Land Command on Twitter

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Turning Point USA is a white nationalist organization.
Justification: Turning Point USA, a conservative activist group operating largely in college and high school campuses, is setting up chapters in Iowa high schools, raising concern among parents who oppose the group’s right-wing approach to public policy and its criticism of progressive programs dealing with racial matters. Some on Twitter have accused Turning Point USA of being a white nationalist hate group. Scholars who study white nationalism and even the group’s critics say calling Turning Point USA white nationalist goes too far.
Sources: Turning Point USA 990 tax return for 2019
Turning Point USA Facebook event page

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Russia is targeting U.S. biological weapons labs in Ukraine invasion.
Justification: There are no U.S.-run biological weapons labs operating in Ukraine. The U.S. Defense Department and the Ukraine Ministry of Health have had a partnership since 2005 to improve public health laboratories and prevent the threat of outbreaks of infectious diseases. That effort is part of the Cooperative Threat Reduction Program, which began in 1991 to reduce the threat of existing weapons of mass destruction programs in former Soviet Republics.
Sources: Center for Arms Control and Nonproliferation
Department of Defense Defense Threat Reduction Agency

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Video shows troops at the Ukraine-Russia border on Jan. 27, 2022.
Justification: A video that was posted online nearly two years ago is being miscast as showing troops gathering at the Ukraine-Russia border in 2022.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Gilbert Gottfried died from the COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: Gilbert Gottfried died from a heart problem caused by an inherited muscular dystrophy disease. He didn’t die from the COVID-19 vaccine.
Sources: Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “Is ANYONE asking how Ron DeSantis was worth $340,000 in 2020 and is now worth $52 million?"
Justification: DeSantis listed his 2020 net worth at $348,832. He has until July 1 to file his 2021 financial disclosure report to the Florida Commission of Ethics. The figure used in the tweet seems to be derived from campaign filings in September 2021, which indicated that DeSantis raked in around $52 million in donations.
Sources: Florida Department of State Division of Elections

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Virginia Tech swimmer Reka Gyorgy tweeted, “My finals spot was stolen by Lia Thomas, who is a biological male.”
Justification: This tweet, purportedly from Virginia Tech swimmer Reka Gyorgy, came from a hoax account. Gyorgy told PolitiFact that she does not have a Twitter account. Gyorgy did write a letter to the NCAA regarding her competition against Lia Thomas, a transgender woman. Twitter permanently suspended the imposter account, @RekaGyorgy_, for violating its policy against the creation of fake accounts, a spokesperson said. Still, the account’s viral tweet about Lia Thomas was shared widely across social media, including in posts by conservative media outlets, pundits and politicians.
Sources: Email correspondence with Sergio Lopez Miro

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “WHO Director-General: The vaccines are being used to kill children.”
Justification: World Health Organization Director-General Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus stumbled over his words, first mispronouncing the word "children" with "kil/cil." He then corrected himself and pronounced the word "children." That led some people to claim he said "kill children." WHO supports the use of vaccines for children and says that there is no evidence that the COVID-19 vaccine has killed children.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Photo shows Empire State Building lit up to support Ukraine.
Justification: This photo was first shared online in 2015 when the Empire State Building lit up in yellow and blue to recognize World Down Syndrome Day.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: A Reddit post shows a parent admitting to forcing their child to continue transitioning by sneaking hormone medication.
Justification: The post isn’t legitimate. The Reddit subthread it was posted on was created so users could roleplay as transgender parents and promote hateful stereotypes of transgender people. The channel has since been removed by Reddit.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Research from Japan shows “ivermectin is effective against omicron in Phase III trial.”
Justification: Reuters corrected a Jan. 31 article that originally reported that a Japanese study found ivermectin to be effective against omicron in human participants in a clinical trial. It was actually non-clinical laboratory research that found the drug to have "antiviral properties." It did not involve humans. Ivermectin is not authorized for use against COVID-19 in the U.S. There are many ongoing studies into its use, including in Japan.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: A Ukrainian combat medic who died in February was seen in a video Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky posted of his visit to see wounded soldiers.
Justification: There is no evidence that Zelensky’s video of him visiting a military hospital was pre-recorded or staged. The woman who appears with Zelensky in the video and in photographs of his visit is Tetiana Ostashchenko — not Inna Derusova, who died in February.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Elon Musk suspended Bill Gates from Twitter.
Justification: Twitter has not suspended Bill Gates’ account, a company spokesperson and Gates spokesperson confirmed. The account remains active. A viral image that purported to show a screenshot of Gates’ account with a suspension notice attached was faked, with some telltale signs that it was not authentic.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Pfizer paid “$2.8 million bribe payment” to the FDA for COVID-19 vaccine approval.
Justification: The Prescription Drug User Fee Act was passed in 1992 and allows the FDA to collect fees from drug companies seeking approval of products. The fees provide funding that helps the agency speed the review and approval process, the FDA said. Spokespersons for Pfizer and the FDA confirmed the payment was for the fee required under the law.
Sources: Public Health and Medical Professionals for Transparency

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Classified documents from Ukraine “confirm without a shadow of a doubt” that the Ukraine government was “covertly preparing an offensive operation against Donbas, scheduled for March 2022.”
Justification: The document isn’t classified, and there are no direct statements in it about an attack on the Donbas. It makes references to a training camp on the opposite side of the country.
Sources: Translation assistance by Irina Kulemzina and Marina Yurieva from Science Feedback

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Greenpeace USA had a banner on Trump International Hotel in Las Vegas making fun of Donald Trump’s genitalia.
Justification: Greenpeace USA tweeted that the video is fake and unrelated to the organization. The creator has acknowledged the video was edited. The creator has in recent years circulated several other doctored videos depicting the same fake yellow sign — with other slogans — on the same Trump hotel.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Video shows Ukrainian crisis actors come to life after pretending to be dead.
Justification: The people under the tarps aren’t crisis actors from Ukraine trying to fool people into thinking they are dead. They were part of a protest against climate change that was held in Vienna, Austria, on Feb. 4.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Sen. Marsha Blackburn made a white power symbol at Ketanji Brown Jackson.
Justification: A photo of Sen. Marsha Blackburn has been miscaptioned to claim that she was flashing a white power symbol at Ketanji Brown Jackson.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Novak Djokovic is the first professional athlete to be banned from a major sporting event for “not taking drugs.”
Justification: Multiple professional athletes like Kyrie Irving, Charlie Beljan and Caster Semenya have been banned, in one form or another, from competing in their sports for refusing to take medication or get the COVID-19 vaccine. Some sporting organizations are issuing vaccine mandates, too. The Olympic committees for Canada and the United States announced that athletes must be fully vaccinated against the virus if they want to compete at the 2022 Winter Olympics. Tennis Australia didn't ban Djokovic from playing. He was deported because of Australia's COVID-19 policies.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: When Donald Trump lost the Iowa caucus to Ted Cruz in 2016, "he immediately cried that Cruz cheated.”
Justification: Following President Donald Trump’s claims that ballots in the 2020 election were fraudulent in some swing states, social media tweeters wrote that Trump claimed that Texas Sen. Ted Cruz’s win in the 2016 Iowa Republican caucuses was because of fraud. Iowa’s precinct caucuses kicked off the 2016 presidential selection process that eventually gave Trump the presidency. This year’s tweeters have good memories; Trump called Cruz’s Iowa win the result of fraud.
Sources: " Would Iowa Republican Party toss caucus results? No

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Says “Jeff Bezos will put 300 (metric tons) of carbon into the atmosphere for 180 seconds in space.”
Justification: Twitter users said Bezos’ ride to space put 300 metric tons of carbon into the air. Liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen fueled his ride, not carbon-based fuels. All rocket launches pose a threat to the ozone layer.
Sources: Center for Space Policy and Strategy

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “40,000 rejected vote by mail ballots in DeKalb County need to be cured by Friday or they will be tossed.”
Justification: The DeKalb County Board of Registration and Elections has debunked the post. The Georgia Secretary of State’s office has told reporters that it expects 3,000 rejections statewide.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “Countless Southwest Airlines employees have walked out of their jobs to oppose the vaccine mandate, causing operations to effectively shut down.”
Justification: Southwest Airlines said its thousands of recent flight cancellations "were not a result of employee demonstrations." The president of the Southwest Airlines Pilots Association, which has taken legal action to temporarily block the company’s COVID-19 vaccine mandate, called claims about a pilot walkout or sickout "false" and said the union is forbidden to take such actions. Flight disruptions such as bad weather can have a cascading effect and lead to many more delays and cancellations.
Sources: Email correspondence with the Federal Aviation Administration

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “Fox News went from 97% reporting to 94% in Virginia. The fraud is so blatant it's not funny anymore.”
Justification: The fact that the turnout tally at one point was reported as lower than it was six minutes earlier merely reflects changes in Fox News' estimates, Fox News says.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: "They’re unable to administer vaccines if the lockdown ends because the emergency ends with it.”
Justification: In the U.S. and the U.K., emergency approvals were granted to vaccine manufacturers separate from any decisions to impose coronavirus restrictions. Lifting such "lockdowns" doesn’t mean vaccines can no longer be administered, experts from both countries said. In the U.S., there was never a full nationwide lockdown. The author of the original tweet about vaccines and lockdowns told us: "To be clear, I have no idea if this is correct or not."
Sources: Statement from the U.K. Department of Health and Social Care
Statement from the U.K. Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency
Statement from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration
U.K. Department of Health & Social Care
U.K. Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: The bomb threat near the U.S. Capitol on Aug. 19 was a false flag.
Justification: There is no evidence that the Aug. 19 bomb threat near the U.S. Capitol was a false flag event led by the FBI or any other entity. The suspect, Floyd Ray Roseberry, has already been charged and appeared in federal court. He confirmed his identity to the FBI. False flag conspiracy theories regularly spread after mass shootings or other major acts of violence, such as the Jan. 6 insurrection at the Capitol.
Sources: Email statement from the U.S. Capitol Police
U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Sen. Joni Ernst's visual aid said liberals wanted to abolish lasagna, among other things.
Justification: Sen. Ernst appeared on the Senate floor to critique President Biden, saying Biden only was listening to Democrats living on "Liberal Fantasy Island." Points on a visual aid said this liberal fantasy land included ending the filibuster, passing the Green New Deal, abolishing I.C.E, defunding the police, increasing taxes, and expanding the courts. A comedian on Twitter changed some of her talking points to "sex blimps," "Marvelous Mrs. Maisel," only letting gay people eat at restaurants, and abolishing lasagna.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: "Bill Gates just admitted that the Pfizer and Moderna mRNA vaccines don’t work well."
Justification: Gates never said that the vaccines don’t work well. His nonprofit, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, called claims stating otherwise false. In a recent interview, Gates said that current vaccines "slightly reduce transmission" and he advocated for funds to be allocated so that researchers can develop new vaccines in the future that halt transmission and offer disease protection at the same time.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: A list shows over 14,000 dead people voted in Wayne County, Michigan.
Justification: A viral tweet purports to show that over 14,000 votes in Wayne County were cast by dead people. According to the state’s voter database, several of the individuals on the list are shown as never having cast an absentee ballot, and at least one woman listed seems to still be alive.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Photos show “diesel generators” at the COP26 climate change conference.
Justification: The photos show electric air handlers, chillers and heaters, according to the manufacturer of the units.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: A video shows the “Taliban hanging someone from a helicopter.”
Justification: The person can be seen in other photographs and videos moving and waving his arms while suspended from a harness. Several news outlets and fact-checkers reported that the person had been tasked with trying to fix a flag on a public building.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Says this crowd video shows the ongoing protests in Cuba.
Justification: This video depicts a crowd in Buenos Aires celebrating the Argentina national football team’s championship win over Brazil for the Copa América cup.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: The percentage of vaccinated employees at United Airlines increased after the mandate because unvaccinated employees left the company.
Justification: Nearly all United Airlines employees complied with the company’s COVID-19 vaccine mandate, according to the company.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Olympic Village has cardboard beds “to prevent Olympians from having sex, and thus risk spreading (COVID-19).”
Justification: Olympic Village is furnished with beds designed out of cardboard. The beds are not "anti-sex" beds. Their purpose is not to prevent the spread of COVID; they were made before the pandemic as renewable material. The beds hold up to about 400 pounds and do not break with sudden movement.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “Black Lives Matter of Atlanta Charged with Wire Fraud, Money Laundering and Allegedly Using almost 500k in Donations For Personal Use.”
Justification: An activist from Ohio was indicted for wire fraud and money laundering. He is accused of using a Facebook page called "Black Lives Matter of Greater Atlanta" to defraud donors. Black Lives Matter was not charged. The Black Lives Matter Global Network Foundation said in September that it is not affiliated with the activist, and it told PolitiFact that hasn’t changed. A local news report from 2016 said he had "parted ways" with the Black Lives Matter of Atlanta movement before launching his organization.
Sources: Black Lives Matter Atlanta on Twitter
Facebook Messenger exchange with Chuck Callesto
Statement from the Black lives Matter Global Network Foundation

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “Boy passes Joe Biden a vial of fresh blood to drink on his way back to the White House”
Justification: A video purporting to show a child handing President Joe Biden a vial of blood to drink is doctored. The original video shows no such thing.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: "Joe Biden forced the U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of North Carolina to resign after 24 people were charged with election fraud and the Mainstream Media never even batted an eyelash."
Justification: Robert Higdon Jr., the U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of North Carolina, resigned in February after President Biden asked most top federal prosecutors to step down. Higdon's office recently announced election-related fraud charges as part of an 18-month investigation. There's no evidence the two events are related and media outlets, including PolitiFact partner WRAL, have been reporting on the probe for a while.
Sources: Press releases from the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Eastern District of North Carolina

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: "Tap water is testing positive for COVID!”
Justification: COVID-19 has not been detected in drinking water, health experts say. The Abbott rapid test shown in a video was not designed to be used with water or other liquids. A doctor who shared the video was recently punished by health authorities in Ontario for spreading misinformation about the pandemic.
Sources: World Health Organization interview with Dr. Sylvie Briand

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: "The CDC lowered the PCR threshold while no longer recording asymptomatic cases...but only for the vaccinated."
Justification: While it’s true the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are no longer officially scrutinizing asymptomatic breakthrough infections, the agency has not "lowered" the general cycle threshold for determining COVID-19 cases.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Email interview with Dr. Anna Durbin

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Says Marjorie Taylor Greene tweeted: “People can’t really be convicted on such flimsy circumstantial evidence as ‘having a similar gait’ or ‘owning the identical shoes’ or ‘being in DC and not having any alibi for that time’ can they?! I don’t recognize this America.”
Justification: This is a fabricated tweet. A spokesperson for Greene said the Congresswoman did not write or post this.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “Police budgets are at their highest they've ever been, there hasn’t actually been any defunding the police.”
Justification: Many police budgets shrank in 2020 — partly in response to the defunding movement and partly because of the fiscal impact of the pandemic and recession. Some major cities that decreased their police budgets last year have reversed course.
Sources: Louisville Metro Government Recommended Detail Budget

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden “is restricting travel for Americans into Mexico, but is keeping the border wide open for illegal aliens to walk right into our country.”
Justification: President Joe Biden has continued a policy — initiated by Donald Trump — to restrict Americans’ travel to Mexico, as a way to fight the spread of COVID-19. The Mexico border is not "wide open" for illegal immigration into the U.S. The vast majority of encounters result in U.S. immigration officials turning people away at the border.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “CDC numbers” show that among children, the Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines have a death rate “174 times higher” than the COVID-19 death rate.
Justification: The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has not reported data for children showing a higher death rate from COVID-19 vaccines than from COVID-19. There is no clear evidence that COVID-19 vaccines have caused any deaths in the U.S., according to the CDC.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “Near Morgantown, WV, a Moderna shipment truck crashed, hazmat dispatched, airspace shut down and now apparently Emergency Response is claiming the Department of Defense took it over.”
Justification: • A truck carrying Moderna vaccines did crash near Morgantown, W.Va., on Aug, 27.• Local emergency management agencies said that the airspace was not shut down and that the Defense Department never dispatched officials to the site of the crash. The cleanup was handled exclusively by local agencies, officials said.
Sources: Email interview with spokesperson for the Department of Health and Human Services

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “Gina Haspel, CIA head is dead!”
Justification: • A CIA spokesperson called the claim "absurd" and confirmed that Haspel is alive and at the office. ​
Sources: Email interview with Nicole de Haay

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Desmond Tutu died on Oct. 20, 2021.
Justification: Desmond Tutu is still alive, his foundation said in a statement. The tweet that spawned rumors about his death came from a hoax account.
Sources: Anglican Church of Southern Africa Diocese of Johannesburg
Desmond and Leah Tutu Legacy Foundation

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Video shows Biden saying “salute the Marines” after hearing the words in an earpiece before his inauguration.
Justification: Joe Biden was heard saying something as he walked through the U.S. Capitol doors held by a pair of U.S. Marines. It is not clear what he said. Some reporters heard, "Good looking Marines." Some social media users claimed that Biden said, "Salute the Marines." They said the comment proved that Biden was repeating instructions fed to him through a hidden earpiece. The video itself, however, does not substantiate that claim.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “You must give EVERY PENNY” of the advance child tax credit payments back when you file your 2021 taxes.
Justification: • On July 15, the IRS began issuing the first advance child tax credit payments.• These are early payments of the "estimated amount of the child tax credit that you may properly claim on your 2021 tax return during the 2022 tax filing season."• A family will have to pay back money received if their household qualifies for a smaller 2021 child tax credit than what the IRS estimated. Divorced parents who alternate years claiming their children as dependents might also encounter a situation where the IRS might send child tax credit payments that would need to be paid back.• These exceptions are expected to be rare and do not equate to the across-the-board mandate that the tweet misleadingly asserts.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: “CDC COVID-19 survival rates” are 99.997% for people ages 0 to 19, 99.98% for people ages 20 to 49, 99.5% for people ages 50 to 69, and 94.6% for people over 70.
Justification: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has not released "COVID-19 survival rates," an agency spokesperson said, and it doesn’t have the data to do so. It’s difficult to pin down a statistic like the "survival rate" with precision.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden received a sudden influx of 138,339 votes in Michigan while Donald Trump received none.
Justification: Conservatives on social media were sharing screenshots of the election map from Decision Desk HQ. The screenshots appeared to show that in one overnight update, Biden received a large number of voters while Trump and other candidates got none. A Decision Desk HQ spokesperson said the change was the result of an error in a file sent by the state. The state corrected the error, and Decision Desk HQ followed. Votes cast legally on or before Election Day will continue to be counted for several days. Counting these votes is part of the process and not a sign of voter fraud, which is rare.

Justification: As of midday on Nov. 4, the number of votes cast in the presidential election was less than the number of registered voters in Wisconsin on Nov. 1. Because Wisconsin allows people to register to vote on Election Day, the total number of registered voters in the 2020 election could change.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Says officials in Washington, D.C., are “jamming all communications.”
Justification: On June 1, #dcblackout trended on Twitter as Black Lives Matter protests raged in Washington, D.C. The hashtag was shared with posts claiming there was a communications blackout in the nation’s capital to quell unrest over the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Washington officials say there was never a blackout. Experts and social media tools suggest #dcblackout was initially spread by fake and hacked Twitter accounts, possibly as part of a coordinated disinformation campaign.

Speaker: tweets

Justification: Brady never said this. The quote was fabricated on a satirical website.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Says Joe Biden and Barack Obama “directly participated in a plot to have #SealTeam6 MURDERED, then arranged a massive cash deal as part of a cover up.”
Justification: President Donald Trump shared a conspiracy theory that falsely claims the Obama administration ordered Navy SEALs to be killed in order to cover up a failed deal with Iran to stage the death of Osama bin Laden. There is no evidence that the Obama administration was responsible for the deaths of 15 members of SEAL Team Six in a 2011 helicopter crash in Afghanistan. Two military investigations concluded the crash was the result of a grenade shot by a Taliban fighter. The source of the conspiracy theory is a story on a website with a history of publishing baseless claims. It relies on the unproven allegations of a falconer.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Says police officers in Austin, Texas, have been “authorized to use LIVE ROUNDS, and lethal force” against protesters.
Justification: No live rounds have been fired on demonstrators in Austin, who marched in protest of racism and police brutality after the death of George Floyd. Officers do not need specific authorization to use deadly force — it is always an option available to officers under the Texas Penal Code, so long as the circumstances meet the parameters outlined by law.
Sources: Phone interview with Travis County District Attorney Margaret Moore

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Says Sen. Chuck Schumer deleted a Feb. 5 tweet criticizing President Donald Trump’s decision to ban some forms of travel to and from China.
Justification: ProPublica maintains a database of politicians' deleted tweets called Politiwoops. Schumer never wrote the tweet some bloggers and conservative websites accused him of deleting.
Sources: Email interview with Schumer spokesman Justin Goodman

Speaker: tweets

Justification: A tweet mischaracterizes a clip of a speech Joe Biden gave in Wisconsin on Sept. 21. In the speech, Biden criticized President Donald Trump for favoring Republican states over Democratic states and said: "I don’t pledge allegiance to red states of America or blue states of America, I pledge allegiance to the United States of America. One nation, indivisible, under God. For real. I’m running as a proud Democrat, but I’m not going to govern as a Democratic president. I’m going to govern as president." He didn’t recite the pledge.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Says Rudy Giuliani "bought $2M in shares of Novartis, a primary supplier of hydroxychloroquine" in early February.
Justification: Novartis is a Swiss pharmaceutical company that manufactures hydroxychloroquine. It has donated 30 million doses to the U.S. While Novartis paid Giuliani a speaker’s fee in 2006, there is no publicly available evidence that he currently has a financial stake in the company. He has denied having one in press reports. Financial disclosure documents indicate that Trump does not have a current connection to Novartis.
Sources: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Says drinking a bleach solution will prevent you from getting the coronavirus.
Justification: Conspiracy theorists are spreading a dangerous claim that says drinking a bleach solution will ward off the coronavirus. The spray, known as Miracle Mineral Solution, is a bleaching agent that fringe groups falsely tout as a "miracle cure" for several ailments. But officials have repeteadly warned consumers against injesting it, saying doing so could cause severe vomiting and liver failure.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: "Not once in his entire career in Washington, D.C., which started way back in 1991, has Democratic Socialist Bernie Sanders ever voted yes on sanctions against Russia."
Justification: Sanders voted in favor of sanctions against Russia in 2017 as an amendment to a larger bill. But Sanders voted against the final legislation. Sanders supported an expansion of the Magnitsky Act, which imposed visa bans and asset freezes on Russian officials. Sanders missed a vote related to sanctions on companies linked to Oleg Deripaska, a Russian billionaire with ties to Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Speaker: tweets
Main Claim: Poll watchers in Philadelphia prevented from entering polling places.
Justification: A poll watcher was denied access to one polling site in Philadelphia because the person in charge of that particular polling place was not up to date on the law, which allows watchers to enter any site, not just the ward and division site specified on the watcher’s certificate, said a spokesperson for Philadelphia City Commissioners. The spokesperson also said that the same poll watcher went to another site and was allowed to go in, and there is "no evidence that it was a systemic problem."
